key_title: Key to the genera of Rosaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C.
source.title: Rosaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Jeanes, J.A.; Jobson, P.C. (1996). Rosaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Carpel usually solitary, free of hypanthium; ovules 2 per carpel, becoming 1 by abortion; fruit a simple 1-seeded drupe; small deciduous trees

Carpels usually more than 1, included in hypanthium or on an elongated receptacle; ovules 1-several per carpel; fruit various, if a drupe then small and forming an aggregate fruit; trees, shrubs or herbs

Carpels numerous (rarely 1 or 2) and free, included in hypanthium or on an elongated receptacle; ovules 1 per carpel; fruit 1-seeded, either drupelets forming an aggregate fruit or achenes included in hypanthium or seated on receptacle; herbs, or shrubs or climbers with prickly cane-like stems

Carpels usually 2–5, either with 2 or more ovules or carpels united to inner wall of hypanthium; fruit usually with more than 1 seed, either a cluster of follicles or a pome with the carpels enclosed in and fused to the enlarged fleshy receptacle; shrubs or small trees
Herbs with unarmed stems
Shrubs or climbers; stems armed with prickles
Plant stoloniferous; leaves 3-foliolate; fruiting receptacle enlarged, spongy, scarlet with minute achenes scattered on its surface (resembling a small strawberry)
Plant tufted or arising from underground rhizomes, if stoloniferous then leaves with more than 3 leaflets; fruiting receptacle not enlarged and colourful
Plant annual; flowers sessile, surrounded and hidden by fused, leaf-like stipules; leaves less than 20 mm long
Plant perennial; flowers not as above; leaves more than 20 mm long

Basal leaves entire, but shallowly and palmately 9–11-lobed, with long bare petioles; inflorescence lax, much-branched, barely longer than basal leaves; flowers minute, greenish-yellow, lacking petals
Leaves pinnately or palmately compound; inflorescence much exceeding basal leaves, or if shorter, then flowers few and moderately large
[link through]
Petals conspicuous, yellow
Petals absent, sepals may be obvious but not yellow
Fruit burr-like; achenes long and slender with hooked or curled ends from the persistent styles; epicalyx bracts narrower than sepals
Fruit a head of achenes borne on a spongy, sometimes elongated receptacle; achenes small, bony, subglobose, style deciduous; epicalyx bracts sepal-like
[link through]
Leaves pinnate with 7 or more leaflets, densely silvery-hairy beneath
Leaves trifoliolate or palmate with not more than 5 leaflets, sparsely to moderately hairy beneath, but never silvery
Achenes with barbed spines or bristles, clustered into spherical or elongated burr-like heads or spikes; flowers bisexual; stems somewhat hairy
Achenes lacking spines or bristles, but aggregated into a spherical or ovoid fruiting head; male and female flowers present on spike; stems glabrous or sparsely pilose
[link through]
Fruiting carpels dry (achenes), free within swollen succulent hypanthium ('hip'); stem prickles readily detachable with age
Fruiting carpels fleshy (drupelets), united in a head on convex receptacle; stem prickles not readily detachable with age
Fruit a cluster of dehiscent follicles; stipules absent
Fruit an indehiscent pome; stipules present although often small or early-caducous
Carpels bony in fruit, separable into pyrenes
Carpels cartilaginous in fruit, fused
Leaves pinnate; florescence a dense, many flowered corymb; pome bright red or orange
Leaves simple, sometimes lobed; flowers ususally in small clusters or panicles; pome colour various
[link through]
Leaves deciduous; pome more than 40 mm diam., more than 2-seeded, green, yellowish or red
Leaves persistent; pome 5–15 mm diam., 1- or 2-seeded, bluish, purplish or dull yellow
Spiny shrub; stipules leafy; pome fragrant, yellow
Small tree, usually lacking spines; stipules caducous, usually narrow; pome green, red, or yellowish
[link through]
Styles fused at base; pome globose, lacking stone-cells; anthers usually yellow
Styles free; pome usually pear-shaped, with numerous stone-cells; anthers usually pink or red
[link through]
[link through]
Brachlets, lower surface of leaves and sepals densely rusty-tomentose; styles 5; pome yellowish
Blanchlets, lower surface of leaves and sepals glabrous or pubescent; styles 2; pome blackish-purple
[link through]
[link through]
Leaves simple, entire; branchlets never spine-tipped
Leaves toothed or lobed; branchlets spine-tipped
Plant deciduous; leaves deeply lobed; petiole more than 10 mm long; flowers more than 8 mm diam.; fruit usually more than 8 mm diam
Plant evergreen; leaves crenulate; petiole to c. 10 mm long; flowers less than 8 mm diam.; fruit to c. 8 mm diam
